description: From Middle English pavis(e) (paveis, pavas), from Anglo-Norman pavis (compare French pavois), from Latin pavensis, probably from Pavia in Italy. Compare Italian pavese.

entries.meaning: (military, history) A very large shield, like a small moveable wall, carried in front to protect all or most of the bearer's body, often with a projecting ridge running vertically down the center.
examples: For in this proceſſe, Parrot nothĩg hath ſurmyſedNo matter pretendyd, nor nothyng enterpryſedBut that metaphora, alegoria with allShall be his protectyon, his pauys and his wall
